Part 1Sports Grounds Safety Authority
	Football Licensing Authority to become Sports Grounds Safety Authority
		The body established by section 8 of, and Schedule 2 to, the FootballSpectators Act 1989—
			is to continue in being, but
			instead of being called the Football Licensing Authority is to be calledthe Sports Grounds Safety Authority.
		Schedule 1 contains further provisions relating to the Authority.
		The expenses of the Authority are to be paid by the Secretary of State.
	Advice to Ministers of the Crown
		The Authority—
			may provide relevant advice to a Minister of the Crown, and
			if requested to do so by a Minister of the Crown, must provide relevantadvice to that Minister.
		“Relevant advice” means—
			advice in relation to safety at sports grounds generally, or
			advice with respect to the exercise of any of the functions of the Ministerin question under the enactments specified in subsection (3).
		The enactments are—
			the Safety of Sports Grounds Act 1975,
			Part 3 of the Fire Safety and Safety of Places of Sport Act 1987 (safety ofstands at sports grounds), and
			the Football Spectators Act 1989.
	Advice to bodies or persons in England and Wales
		The Authority may provide advice relating to safety at sports grounds inEngland or Wales to—
			local authorities, or
			subject to subsection (2), other bodies or persons.
		The Authority may not under subsection (1) provide advice to—
			a Minister of the Crown, or
			a body or person specified in section 4(1)(a), (b) or (c).
	Advice to bodies or persons outside England and Wales
		The Authority may, if the conditions in subsection (2) are met, provideadvice relating to the safety of sports grounds to—
			the government of a territory outside the United Kingdom,
			an international organisation, or
			a body or person not falling within paragraph (a) or (b) whose functions,activities or responsibilities relate in whole or in part to the safety ofsports grounds outside England and Wales.
		The conditions are that—
			the provision of the advice is at the request of the body or personconcerned, and
			the Secretary of State consents to the provision of the advice.
	Supplementary 
		The Authority may, with the consent of the Secretary of State, charge a feefor the provision of advice under—
			section 4 (advice to bodies or persons outside England and Wales), or
			if the advice is provided at the request of the recipient, section 3(advice to bodies or persons in England and Wales).
		A fee charged under subsection (1) must not exceed the cost of providingthe advice.
		Fees received by the Authority by virtue of subsection (1) are to betreated for the purposes of section 1(3) as reducing the expenses of theAuthority.
		A consent under section 4(2)(b) or subsection (1) may be given—
			generally, 
			in relation to any particular advice, or
			in relation to advice of a particular description.
		In this Part—
			“local authority” and “sports ground” have the same meaning as in theSafety of Sports Grounds Act 1975 (see section 17(1) of that Act), and
			“Minister of the Crown” has the same meaning as in the Ministers of theCrown Act 1975.
Part 2Supplementary
	Consequential amendments etc.
		Schedule 2 contains consequential amendments.
		Schedule 3 contains repeals and revocations.
	Extent 
		This Act extends to England and Wales only (subject to subsection (2)).
		An amendment or repeal of a provision by Schedule 2 (consequentialamendments) or 3 (repeals and revocations) has the same extent as thatprovision.
	Commencement 
		Part 1 and the Schedules come into force on such day as the Secretary ofState may by order made by statutory instrument appoint.
		Such an order may—
			appoint different days for different purposes;
			include transitional or saving provisions.
		This Part comes into force on the day on which this Act is passed.
	Short title
		This Act may be cited as the Sports Grounds Safety Authority Act 2011.
